children.name: be over sb’s head
children.definition: to be much too complicated or technical for sb to understand:
examples: ▪ It was obvious from her expression that what I was saying was over her head.

children.name: be way/completely over somebody’s head
examples: ▪ I went to the lecture, but it was way over my head.

children.name: can’t make head or tail of
children.definition: can’t make head or/nor tail ofalsocan’t makes heads or tails (out) ofAmerican  informal to be unable to understand sth at all because it is very complicated or confusing:
examples: ▪ I just can’t make head or tail of this train timetable.
▪ I couldn’t make head or tail of this book, and had real trouble finishing it.
▪ Consumers can’t always make heads or tails out of the way nutrition is labeled on a food package.

children.name: I can’t think
children.definition: /can’t imagine you say I can’t think or I can’t imagine how or why someone does something when you cannot think of any reasonable explanation why someone should do it, and are very surprised that they do:

children.name: I can’t think/can’t imagine why/how etc
examples: ▪ He wants to join the army -- I can’t think why.
▪ How such a stupid man ever got to be a politician, I just can’t imagine.

children.name: be a mystery to me
children.definition: /be beyond me/beats me spoken say this when you cannot understand why sth happens or how someone does something, and you find it very surprising:

children.name: be a mystery to me/be beyond me/beats me how/what/why etc
examples: ▪ It’s a mystery to me how he can get so much work done in such a short time.
▪ Why anyone would willingly do that job is beyond me.
it beats me/it’s beyond me etc.

children.name: ▪ ‘Why does she stay with her husband then?’ ‘It beats me.’
vague
children.definition: /veɪg/  unclear, especially because not enough details are given:
examples: mơ hồ, mập mờ do không chi tiết
▪ There have been vague rumours of a coup.vague idea
▪ I only had a vague idea of where the place was.vague about
▪ He was rather vague about the reasons why he never finished school.
vaguely[adverb]
▪ The man is described vaguely as ‘medium build with brown hair’.

children.name: imprecise
children.definition: /ˌɪmprɪˈsaɪs◂/  words or statements that are imprecise are unclear because they do not describe or explain something in an exact way when this is necessary:

children.name: không chính xác, không đúng, mơ hồ
examples: ▪ Many of the terms used in this book are imprecise.
▪ She gave me directions to the hotel, but they were, shall we say, somewhat imprecise.

children.name: muddled/garbled
children.definition: /ˈmʌdld, ˈgɑːʳbəld/  if something that someone tells you is muddled or garbled, it is very unclear and confusing because they themselves have not really understood it very well:

children.name: lộn xộn
examples: ▪ I heard a garbled version of the story from one of my students.
▪ Conroy made some muddled statement about how company policy has to be observed in these situations.
▪ The old woman’s directions were so garbled that I just rolled up the window and drove on.

children.name: difficult
children.definition: not easy to do, understand, etc
examples: That’s a good question, but it’s a difficult one to answer.

children.name: difficult for
examples: ▪ The reading exercise was very difficult for most of the children.

children.name: ddifficult to see/hear/ describe etc
examples: ▪ The insects are so small that they are difficult to see without using a microscope.

children.name: it is difficult (forsb) to do something
examples: ▪ It’s very difficult to find people who are willing to do the job.

children.name: find it difficult to dosth
examples: ▪ Until now, patients often found it difficult to get information about their rights.

children.name: make it difficult forsbto dosth
examples: ▪ My mother’s illness makes it difficult for her to walk.

children.name: hard
children.definition: not easy todoorunderstand, etc.Hardis less formal thandifficultand is very common in spoken English:
examples: ▪ I thought the exam was really hard.
▪ The hardest thing about moving to a new place was meeting new people.

children.name: it is hard (forsb) to dosth
examples: ▪ It’s hard to see the stage from here.
▪ It was hard for me to understand her - her accent was very strong.

children.name: find it hard to dosth
examples: ▪ I find it hard to believe that he didn’t know the gun was loaded.

children.name: tough
children.definition: very difficult to do or deal with - use thisabout jobs, decisions, questions, or problems:khó nhằn
examples: The judge asked the lawyers on both sides some very tough questions.
The governor is trying to show voters that he’s able to deal with the toughest issues facing Ohio today.

children.name: easier said than done
children.definition: spokenuse this to tell someone that something is much more difficult than they think it is:nói thì dễ làm thì khó
examples: Talking calmly to a screaming child sounds like a good idea, but any parent will tell you it’s easier said than done.

children.name: a tall order
children.definition: be  spoken use this aboutsthdifficult you have been asked to do, especially when you do not think it is likely you will be able to do it:yêu cầu, đòi hỏi cao
examples: ‘Can you finish the work by Friday?’ ‘Sounds like a tall order to me, but I’ll see what I can do.’

children.name: not an easy
children.definition: .../be no easy... use this to say that something is difficult to do or make:
examples: Finding a solution to the present crisis in the region is no easy task.
not the easiest...[adjective phrase] not the easiest...to do spoken use this to say that it is difficult to do something:
I’ll drive you there -- it’s not the easiest place to get to if you don’t have a car.
I tried to explain it to him, but he’s not the easiest person to talk to.

children.name: not an easy task/ job/ decision
examples: The roads are often dangerous, and getting food to the villages has not been an easy task.

children.name: a pain
children.definition: (in the neck)/ə ˌpeɪn (ɪn ðə ˈnek)/  spoken something that is difficult and annoying to do or deal with:

children.name: vật phiền toái, của nợ
examples: ▪ It was a pain - I had to read more than 200 articles - but I learned a lot from it.
Quả là phiền toái- tôi phải đọc hơn 200 bài baso- nhưng tôi học được nhiều điều.
▪ Getting across town at rush hour is a real pain in the neck.
Băng qua đường vào giờ cao điểm quả là một điều phiền toái.

children.name: complicated and needing a lot of care
tricky
children.definition: difficult to deal with or do because it is complicated and full of problems:phức tạp, rắm rối
examples: Getting the two sides of the mobile to balance is tricky.
I can get you tickets for the show but it’ll be tricky.
Merging the two companies was bound to be tricky.

children.name: be (a) tricky businessbe difficult to do
examples: Refuelling a plane in mid-air is a tricky business.

children.name: fiddly
children.definition: British English informaldifficult to do because you have to handle very small objects:tỉ mỉ, cầu kỳ

children.name: fiddlyjob
examples: He managed to fix the television, but it was a time-consuming and fiddly job.
Fixing the TV was a fiddly job .

children.name: fiddly to eat/ mend/open etc
examples: I don’t like shrimps -- they’re so fiddly to eat.

children.name: not clear and therefore difficult to understand
unclear
children.definition: /not clear/ʌnˈklɪəʳ, nɒt ˈklɪəʳ/
examples: ▪ It is not clear why the disease affects some people and not others.
▪ The circumstances surrounding his death are still unclear.

children.name: obscure
children.definition: a statement, joke, or idea that is obscure is very difficult to understand because the meaning is not clear unless it is carefully explained to you: tối nghĩa
examples: Best’s art is eccentric and obscure.
Publishers would not print his earlier poetry because they felt it was too obscure.

children.name: ambiguous
children.definition: /æmˈbɪgjuəs/  havingmorethanonepossible meaning and therefore confusing and unclear:
examples: ambiguously[adverb]
▪ The contract was worded ambiguously.
ambiguity/ˌæmbɪˈgjuːəti, ˌæmbəˈgjuːəti/ [countable/uncountable noun]
▪ The report is full of ambiguities.

children.name: lưỡng nghĩa, mơ hồ, nhập nhằng
examples: ▪ The document’s ambiguous wording makes it very difficult to follow.

children.name: deliberately ambiguousintended to be difficult to understand
examples: ▪ The last part of her letter was deliberately ambiguous.

children.name: not clear
children.definition: unclear//ʌnˈklɪəʳ, nɒt ˈklɪəʳ/
examples: ▪ It is not clear why the disease affects some people and not others.
▪ The circumstances surrounding his death are still unclear.
không rõ ràng
unclear/not clear/ʌnˈklɪəʳ, nɒt ˈklɪəʳ/ [adjective] không rõ ràng
▪ It is unclear how the man died.
▪ The instructions aren’t very clear.
▪ The terms of our tenancy agreement are somewhat unclear.
▪ The reasons for his resignation are still not clear.
unclear/not clear about
▪ His ideas are good, but he’s very unclear about how he’s going to achieve them.
unclear/not clear whether/what/why etc
▪ It’s not clear why Parks didn’t go straight to the police.
▪ It is unclear whether the she will agree to the new arrangements.

children.name: with a lot of different parts and difficult to understand
complicated
children.definition: consisting of a lot of different parts or details and therefore difficult to understand:phức tạp
examples: I didn’t realize programming the VCR would be so complicated.
The brain is like a very powerful, very complicated computer.

children.name: the complicated problem of bringing peace to the Middle East
examples: For young children, getting dressed is a complicated business.

children.name: very/extremely/immensely/highly etc complicated
examples: Mental illness is a very complicated subject.
RegisterIn written English, people often usecomplexrather thancomplicated, because it sounds more formal:
The problem is verycomplex.

children.name: complex
children.definition: a complex process, relationship etc is difficult to understand because it has a lot of parts that are all connected in different ways :phức tạp
examples: The chemical processes involved are extremely complex.
the complex relationship between government and the media
acomplex systemof highways
Photosynthesis is ahighly complexprocess.
Peter seemed to have an instant understanding of the most complex issues.
It was a very complex relationship between two complex people.
complexity[U]C2
complexity of
There is increasing recognition of the complexity of the causes of poverty.
a design of great complexity
I don’t think you fully understood the complexity of his argument.

children.name: intricate
children.definition: having a lot of small parts or details - use this especially about something that is cleverly designed or made :phức tạp
examples: ▪Lasers are used to cut intricate designs in wood.
▪The farmers use an intricate system of drainage canals.
▪the intricate workings of a watch
▪intricate patterns of coloured marble

children.name: convoluted
children.definition: too complicated and difficult to understand - use this especially about someone’s language or arguments, or about a system :“quấn, xoắn”xoắn não
examples: He always uses a lot of convoluted arguments to support his theories, but no one’s ever impressed.
James’s books are full of long paragraphs and convoluted sentences, which many people do not find appealing.
Procedures for government funding have become more convoluted.

children.name: tortuous
children.definition: much too long and complicated, and therefore confusing and annoying :“quanh co, lòng vòng”, dài dòng
examples: The book begins with a long, tortuous introduction.
At last, an end to the tortuous negotiations was in sight.

children.name: involved
children.definition: very long and complicated - use this about a system, description, or explanation that you think should be made simpler :rắc rối, phức tạp
examples: The system for choosing candidates is very involved, and I won’t go into it here.
Adopting a child can be a long involved process.

children.name: incomprehensible
children.definition: impossible to understand:
examples: ▪ His English was incomprehensible.

children.name: it is incomprehensible that
examples: ▪ It is incomprehensible that a tragedy like this could be joked about.

children.name: incomprehensible to
examples: ▪ The leaflet was written in jargon that would have been totally incomprehensible to anyone outside the profession.

children.name: incoherent
children.definition: /ˌɪnkəʊˈhɪərənt◂/  incoherent speech is very difficult to understand, especially because the person who is speaking is drunk, ill, or very angry:
examples: ▪ Harris gave rambling, incoherent answers to questions about the case.
▪ She was clearly very ill, and at times her speech was incoherent.

children.name: unintelligible
children.definition: speech or writing that is unintelligible is impossible to understand because it is not clear, simple, or well planned:
examples: ▪ Joe muttered something unintelligible, clasping his head in his hands.
▪ Radio transmissions were often cut off or unintelligible.
Her note was practically unintelligible.
I liked the music but the lyrics were completely unintelligible.

children.name: inaccessible
children.definition: difficult to understand or admireOPP accessible: “khó với tới”
examples: Stockhausen’s music is thought to be difficult and inaccessible.
I found his lecture completely inaccessible.

children.name: inaccessible to
examples: Why is opera so inaccessible to so many people?
